newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat ends up, gains pared by crop tour data.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat ends up, gains pared by crop tour data.

text.p: CBOT wheat futures ended higher Wednesday but uncertainty over data from ongoing U.S. Plains crop tours spurred nervous selling that pared gains late, traders and market observers said.
"We have some reports that the Oklahoma crop is down and the Kansas crop will likely be better than last year," said Sid Love, grain analyst with Kropf and Love Consulting. "
"It's really a mixed bag of tricks out there," he said.
Many crop scouts on the Wheat Quality Council tour were reporting less damage than initially expected from an April freeze, and those reports prompted late selling, traders said.
Other supportive factors in the Wednesday's wheat market included continued commercial buying and ideas that the market was oversold and due for a technical bounce, traders said.
"I think more than anything else the market was just oversold," said a floor trader.

Traders again noted moderate buying linked to firms with ties to the cash market. On Tuesday, wheat prices fell to levels that were attractive to end-users, and there was a number of export tenders for U.S. wheat overnight.
CBOT wheat futures ended one to five cents per bushel higher, with July up 1-3/4 at $4.04-1/4 per bushel.
